results.title: Farm Machinery Maintenance
results.creator_credit: Neville Bletcher, Eric Thompson, Solarchrome and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: ‘Farm Machinery Maintenance’ is an instructional film made for the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry, designed for an audience of farmers and agricultural workers. The film’s narrator outlines the importance of maintaining farm machinery and equipment to ensure their function and longevity. The film offers an interesting insight into farming methods of the 1950s, with footage of rural farms, machines and tools. As with many educational films of the era, the film displays a (now outdated) gender division of stereotypical roles for men and for women, with men operating the heavy machinery while women serve tea and pick fruit.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Neville Bletcher, Eric Thompson, Solarchrome and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Australia's wheat
results.creator_credit: Kit Guyatt, John Gray, Heinz Fenke, Lilias Fraser, Stephen Carthew, AWB Limited and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: Provides an outline of the Australian wheat industry, a brief history and general view of growing, harvesting, bulk handling and processing, research and marketing. Shows the industry from the historical beginnings at Experiment Farm and the growing colony of New South Wales, to mechanical innovation, nationwide research and modern transport and handling. Explains the farmer’s work through each season and traces the marketing of the grain from the country silo to the consumers overseas.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kit Guyatt, John Gray, Heinz Fenke, Lilias Fraser, Stephen Carthew, AWB Limited and Fraser Castle Productions

results.title: [George Malins Home Movies: Reel 17]
results.brief_description:
George William Malins (1910–2007) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to 1970s. According to his daughter, George was ‘optimistic, happy and enthusiastic’, an outlook reflected in his films which are a history of home life and a love of travel.

George came to Australia from England as a young man by way of the merchant navy, after having seen South America and some of Asia. He met his future wife Sybil, who was impressed by George’s world travels and his dreams for the future.

The family lived in the Melbourne suburb of North Balwyn, spending their summers camping at Wye River on the Victorian coast often with extended family and friends.

George and Sybil must have shared a sense of adventure as they eventually sold the family home and sailed on the ‘SS Orontes’ to England, travelling around Britain for two years.

The George Malins Home Movie Collection was donated to ACMI by the creator’s daughter, Ruth Hargrave. The films were made on 16mm film.

This film shows a family picnic in a parkland or bush, featuring a 1950s style car. The family pose for the camera, smile and wave. The film is a good example of picnicking and fashion of the period.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 a family picnic beside a 1950s style car in a bush or parkland setting
00:00:26:00 great shot of a young boy grimacing with effort as he pops open a bottle with a utensil
00:00:39:00 close-up of a woman holding a baby
00:01:07:00 a man and woman hug surrounded by trees
00:01:13:00 the family exit the car in the driveway of a brick house, waving and smiling at the camera; the house features a large striped awning over the window

results.title: A Hundred-Odd Years From Now
results.creator_credit: Fred Schepisi, Australian Dried Fruits Association and Film House Company
results.brief_description: An advertising film with a difference: Into a strange computerised future where women “run things” by controlling huge colourful computers that go bleep booble bob bob ping etc, comes Yockoo, the boy from the bush, with his satchel of dried fruits. Slowly the women overcome their cold, futuristic ways in light of Yockoo’s size, shape and overall manliness. Eventually they unearth their deep feminine sexuality and cook Yockoo a feast of dried fruit dishes using cooking utensils from their local museum. Music by Frank Smith, Photographed by Lars Gundlach, Written and designed by Weatherhead & Stitt.

results.title: Egami
results.creator_credit: Victorian Women's Film Unit and Sue Ford
results.brief_description: In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Melbourne landmarks are totalitarian monuments, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.

constellations_primary.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_primary.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Victorian Women’s Film Unit and Sue Ford
results.description: In Sue Ford’s radical short film Egami, Melbourne’s imposing Shrine of Remembrance is rebadged the “New Settlers’ Temple of Wars” by the artist’s intergalactic visitor, who observes from a spaceship. The Shrine is one of many familiar Melbourne landmarks rendered as totalitarian monuments, which have usurped the lands of ‘the Dreaming People’, of which there is no sign left except in Swanston St souvenir stores. In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Hamer Hall is a survival bunker, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.
description_for_label: In Sue Ford’s radical short film Egami, Melbourne’s imposing Shrine of Remembrance is rebadged the “New Settlers’ Temple of Wars” by the artist’s intergalactic visitor, who observes from a spaceship. The Shrine is one of many familiar Melbourne landmarks rendered as totalitarian monuments, which have usurped the lands of ‘the Dreaming People’, of which there is no sign left except in Swanston St souvenir stores. In Egami, fashion mannequins are interpreted as women for sale, statues are erected for white men and war, and Hamer Hall is a survival bunker, in a work that’s exploration of Australian identity and feminism is still relevant today.

results.title: The Story of Holmesglen Concrete Housing Project
results.creator_credit: Housing Commission of Victoria and Herschells Films
results.brief_description: The Housing Commission of Victoria has a huge project at Holmesglen, a suburb of Melbourne, for the manufacture of prefabricated houses. All components of a modern house or a block of flats are constructed at this factory and transported in bulk to the place of erection. Concrete walls, chimneys, fences, tiles for roofs, plumbing units, wooden door cupboards and other fittings are all shown under construction and are then shown being fitted into place as the house is erected. Credit is given to the research work being carried out by the CSIRO Building Research Division, particularly in regard to a new type of light weight concrete which has been developed there.

results.title: Low deposit, easy terms
results.brief_description: Sue Ford was one of the first feminist photographers and filmmakers in Australia, initiating her practice during the early 1960s in Melbourne. An active member of many feminist film co-operatives, her works explore Australian identity and feminism, excavating the effects of Australia’s colonial past through playful, innovative and experimental films. In Low Deposit Easy Terms, Ford interrogates Australia’s obsession with car culture, but instead of open Outback roads, the viewer tours inner-city car dealerships, home garages and junkyards where life struggles to grow.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

In Low deposit, easy terms, Ford interrogates Australia’s obsession with car culture, but instead of open Outback roads, the viewer tours inner-city car dealerships, home garages and junkyards where life struggles to grow.

results.title: [Royal Visit, Victoria, 1954: Pre-Release Footage: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 10 shows more of the special race-meeting held at Flemington Racecourse, the tennis at Kooyong, and a service held at St. Paul’s Cathedral.

Detailed Description Reel 10:

Opens with Title “Duke of Edinburgh Australian Cup” followed by race footage of the last stretch and race finish. 00:00:25:00 Title “Queen Elizabeth Stakes”, followed by footage of horses and jockeys in the mounting yard. 00:00:50:00 footage of entire race to 00:01:12:00 then horses - with jockeys still mounted - exit to mounting yards. 00:01:40:00 to 00:03:23:00 the Queen presents winners’ trophies. 00:03:44:00 Title “Tennis at Kooyong”, followed by shot of Kooyong Stadium (Kooyong Tennis Centre) scoreboard displaying “International Match Australia v Sth. Africa”, footage of game and crowd scenes. 00:04:05:00 - 00:05:34:00 Queen and Duke arrive separately and move to seats amongst crowd. 00:05:45:00 - 00:06:35:00 Queen presents trophies in middle of court. 00:06:36:00 Title “Divine Service Cathedral Church of St. Paul Sunday, 28th. February, 1954”, followed by shots of St Paul’s Cathedral and crowds outside. 00:07:01:0 a good shot of Flinders Street Station and the station verandas along Swanston St. 00:07:27:00 Queen and Duke arrive and enter Cathedral. 00:08:01:00 couple leave and re-enter car, driving off through waving crowds. Dignitaries and churchmen on steps of Cathedral, at 00:08:41:00 Robert Menzies (then Prime Minister of Australia) is seen leaving, acknowledging crowd and getting into car.

Africa”, footage of game and crowd scenes. 00:04:05:00 - 00:05:34:00 Queen and Duke arrive separately and move to seats amongst crowd. 00:05:45:00 - 00:06:35:00 Queen presents trophies in middle of court. 00:06:36:00 Title “Divine Service Cathedral Church of St. Paul Sunday, 28th. February, 1954”, followed by shots of St Paul’s Cathedral and crowds outside. 00:07:01:0 a good shot of Flinders Street Station and the station verandas along Swanston St. 00:07:27:00 Queen and Duke arrive and enter Cathedral. 00:08:01:00 couple leave and re-enter car, driving off through waving crowds. Dignitaries and churchmen on steps of Cathedral, at 00:08:41:00 Robert Menzies (then Prime Minister of Australia) is seen leaving, acknowledging crowd and getting into car.
description_for_label:
The 1954 visit to Australia of newly-crowned Queen Elizabeth II with her husband and consort Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, was a cause of much celebration - and an occasion for much pageantry - in Victoria. Elizabeth was the first reigning monarch to visit Australia, and the young and popular royal couple attracted intense interest wherever they visited on their extensive Australian tour.

This silent, pre-release footage - much of which eventually comprised sections of the official Victorian film release - follows the visiting couple on their journey throughout the state; including numerous regional centres as well as major sites and events in Melbourne. It shows not only the “official” portrait of this historic royal visit, but also dwells on the reactions of the Victorian people; crowds of whom waited by roadsides and railways, on city streets and in small country towns, for a glimpse of the monarch.

As well as focusing on the history of the 1954 royal visit, the footage thus also gives us a unique and invaluable look back in time at some of the buildings, streetscapes, vehicles, cameras, fashions and crowd behaviours of the mid-1950s in Victoria.

Reel 10 shows more of the special race-meeting held at Flemington Racecourse, the tennis at Kooyong, and a service held at St. Paul’s Cathedral.

Detailed Description Reel 10:

Opens with Title “Duke of Edinburgh Australian Cup” followed by race footage of the last stretch and race finish. 00:00:25:00 Title “Queen Elizabeth Stakes”, followed by footage of horses and jockeys in the mounting yard. 00:00:50:00 footage of entire race to 00:01:12:00 then horses - with jockeys still mounted - exit to mounting yards. 00:01:40:00 to 00:03:23:00 the Queen presents winners’ trophies. 00:03:44:00 Title “Tennis at Kooyong”, followed by shot of Kooyong Stadium (Kooyong Tennis Centre) scoreboard displaying “International Match Australia v Sth. Africa”, footage of game and crowd scenes. 00:04:05:00 - 00:05:34:00 Queen and Duke arrive separately and move to seats amongst crowd. 00:05:45:00 - 00:06:35:00 Queen presents trophies in middle of court. 00:06:36:00 Title “Divine Service Cathedral Church of St. Paul Sunday, 28th. February, 1954”, followed by shots of St Paul’s Cathedral and crowds outside. 00:07:01:0 a good shot of Flinders Street Station and the station verandas along Swanston St. 00:07:27:00 Queen and Duke arrive and enter Cathedral. 00:08:01:00 couple leave and re-enter car, driving off through waving crowds. Dignitaries and churchmen on steps of Cathedral, at 00:08:41:00 Robert Menzies (then Prime Minister of Australia) is seen leaving, acknowledging crowd and getting into car.
